Event leading to space exploration: First telescopic observation of the night sky: discovery of the Galilean moons, lunar craters and the phases of Venus.
First exposition of the rocket equation based on Newton's third law of motion: Treatise on the Motion of Rockets.
First clear telescopic photograph of another world: the Moon.
First proper observation of other galaxies which are termed "whirlpool nebulae".
A Journey Through Space makes first proposal of using rockets for space flight.

Mission success: Publication of Exploration of the Universe with Rocket-Propelled Vehicles[1] that showed physical space exploration was theoretically possible, including the Tsiolkovsky rocket equation, multi staged rockets and using liquid oxygen and liquid hydrogen in liquid propellant
Goddard files for and is subsequently awarded U.S. patents on multistage and liquid-fueled rockets.
First observation of an extrasolar planet (exoplanet) round Van Maanen 2 although it is not recognised as such at the time.
Goddard's widely influential paper "A Method of Reaching Extreme Altitudes" discussed solid- and liquid-fueled rocketry.
Die Rakete zu den Planetenräumen ("By Rocket into Planetary Space") self-published after its rejection as a doctoral thesis.
Society for Studies of Interplanetary Travel founded.
Mission name: Members include Konstantin Tsiolkovsky, Friedrich Zander, Yuri Kondratyuk

Mission success: Goddard launches the first liquid-fueled rocket.
Verein für Raumschiffahrt (Society for Space Travel) formed; it includes many top European rocket scientists.
Завоевание межпланетных пространств (The Conquest of Interplanetary Space) discusses rocket mechanics and orbital effects including the gravitational slingshot.
Das Problem der Befahrung des Weltraums – der Raketen-Motor (The Problem of Space Travel – The Rocket Motor) discusses space travel and its potential uses for scientific experiments.
British Interplanetary Society founded.
First detection of radio waves from an astronomical object.
Establishment of the Soviet rocket research lab Reactive Scientific Research Institute (RNII) by combining the Group for the Study of Reactive Motion (GIRD) with the Gas Dynamics Laboratory (GDL).
Mission name: Key people Sergei Korolev & Valentin Glushko

Mission success: First spaceflight in history. First man-made object in space (later defined as above the Kármán line).
Article in Wireless World, "Extra-Terrestrial Relays — Can Rocket Stations Give Worldwide Radio Coverage?" makes first discussion of geostationary satellites as a means of communication.
First space research flight (cosmic radiation experiments).
First pictures of Earth from 105 km (65 mi).
First animals in space (fruit flies).
First two-stage liquid-fueled rocket, that sets a record altitude of 244 miles (393 km) (WAC Corporal missile mounted onto a V-2 rocket).
First mammal in space (Albert II, a rhesus monkey). First primate in space.
First rocket to pass the thermopause and enter the exosphere. At 682 miles (1,098 km) altitude and 3,335 miles range, the 3-stage Jupiter-C breaks both records and achieves MACH 18 velocity.

Mission achievements: First artificial satellite. First man-made signals from space.
First mammal in orbit, the dog Laika.
Confirmed existence of the Van Allen radiation belt.
First use of solar power in space. The oldest artificial object still in space.
First rocket to reach Earth escape velocity. First spacecraft to attempt to impact the Moon's surface. First artificial object in heliocentric orbit. First detection of solar wind.
First photograph of Earth from Earth orbit.
First spacecraft to impact another celestial body (the Moon). First delivery of national pennants to a celestial body.
First photos of another world from space: the far side of the Moon. First gravity assist.

Mission success: First solar probe.
First plants and animals to return alive from Earth orbit.
First rocket engine fired in space.
First hominidae in space (chimpanzee Ham). First tasks performed in space.
First launch from Earth orbit of upper stage into a heliocentric orbit. First mid-course corrections. First spin-stabilisation.
First human spaceflight (Yuri Gagarin). First human-crewed orbital flight.
First human-piloted space flight (Alan Shepard). First human-crewed suborbital flight.
First planetary flyby (within 100,000 km of Venus – no data returned).
First crewed space flight lasting over twenty four hours by Gherman Titov, who is also the first to suffer from space sickness.
First orbital solar observatory.
First spacecraft to impact the far side of the Moon.
First dual crewed spaceflight. First communication between two crewed space vehicles in orbit. First person to float freely in microgravity.
First auroral research rocket launched into the ionosphere.
First Mars flyby (11,000 km) but contact was lost.
First planetary flyby with data returned (Venus). First successful planetary science mission.
First woman in space (Valentina Tereshkova).
First reusable crewed spacecraft (suborbital).
First multi-person crew (3) in orbit.
First space walk/extra-vehicular activity (Alexei Leonov).
First crewed spacecraft to change orbit.
First flyby of Mars (returned pictures).
First photographs of another planet from deep space (Mars).
First orbital rendezvous (parallel flight, no docking).
First soft landing on another world (the Moon). First photos from another world.
First impact into another planet (Venus).
First orbital docking between two spacecraft.
First artificial satellite around another world (the Moon).
First picture of Earth from another astronomical object (the Moon). First probe to map the Moon.
First polar orbit around the Moon.
First photos of the Lunar south pole.
First automated (crewless) docking.
First liftoff from another celestial body (the Moon).
First animals and plants to leave Earth orbit and travel to and around the Moon. First lunar spacecraft to be recovered successfully.
First orbital ultraviolet observatory.
First human excursion beyond low Earth orbit. First in-person observations of Earth from a distance. First Trans-Earth injection.
First human flight to another celestial body (the Moon) and to enter its gravitational influence.
First docking between two crewed spacecraft in Earth orbit. First crew exchange in space.
First spacecraft to parachute in Venus's atmosphere, lost contact before landing.
First docking of two crewed spacecraft around another celestial body. First lunar mission to include a lunar landing module.
First human on another celestial body (the Moon). First words spoken from another world.
First space launch from another celestial body. First sample return from another celestial body.
First rendezvous on the surface of a celestial body. First meet up between human explorers and a robotic spacecraft in space (on the Moon).
First automatic sample return from the Moon.
First rover on another celestial body (the Moon). First lunar rover.
First X-ray orbital observatory.
First soft landing on another planet (Venus). First signals from another planet.
First space station.
First crewed orbital observatory.
First motor vehicle on another celestial body (Lunar Roving Vehicle).
First spacecraft to orbit another planet (Mars).
First spacecraft to impact another planet (Mars).
First soft landing on Mars. First signals from Martian surface. First photograph from Martian surface.
First spacecraft on a trajectory out of the solar system. First spacecraft to use all-nuclear electrical power (SNAP-19 RTGs).
First spacecraft to enter the asteroid belt. First spacecraft beyond the orbit of Mars.
First orbital gamma ray observatory.
First mission sent to study Mercury.
First flyby of Jupiter. First spacecraft beyond the Inner Solar System.
First spacecraft to return data on a long-period comet.
First mission to explore two planets in a single mission (Mercury and Venus). First photograph of Venus from space. First use of solar wind for spacecraft orientation.
First flyby of Mercury.
First spacecraft to flyby the same planet multiple times (Mercury).
First multinational crewed mission.
First spacecraft to orbit Venus.
First successful photos from the surface of another planet (Venus).
First successful photos and soil samples from the surface of Mars.
First real time remotely operated ultraviolet orbital observatory.
First spacecraft to orbit the Sun at Lagrange 1.
First extended (multi-year) orbital exploration of Venus (from 1978 to 1992).
Jupiter flyby (closest approach 349,000 km) Encounters with five Jovian moons. Discovery of volcanism on Io.
First flyby of Saturn. First photograph of Titan from deep space.
Saturn flyby (closest approach 124,000 km), close encounter of Titan and encounters with a dozen other moons.
First reusable crewed orbital spacecraft (Space Shuttle).
First Venus soil samples First sound recording of another world (Venus).
First spacecraft to conduct a deep survey of Earth's magnetic tail.
First mixed gender crew aboard space station, and first woman, Svetlana Savitskaya, on space station.
First plants grown in space (Arabidopsis).
First Infrared orbital observatory.
First spacecraft beyond the orbit of Neptune. First spacecraft beyond all Solar System planets.
First untethered spacewalk (Bruce McCandless II).
First spacewalk by a woman (Svetlana Savitskaya).
First balloon deployed on another planet (Venus).
First spacecraft to flyby a comet (21P/Giacobini-Zinner).[note 1]
First spacecraft to flyby Uranus.
First consistently inhabited long-term research space station.
First close up observations of a comet (Halley's Comet, 596 kilometers).
First suspected detection of an exoplanet (Gamma Cephei Ab).[note 2]
Mission name: Astronomers Bruce Campbell, Gordon Walker and Stephenson Yang.

Mission success: First astrometric satellite.
First spacecraft to flyby Neptune. First spacecraft to study all four of the solar system's giant planets at close range.
First orbital cosmic microwave observatory.
First photograph of the whole Solar System (Family Portrait).
First telescope designed to be repaired in space.
First time a spacecraft coming from deep space uses the Earth for a gravity-assist manoeuvre.
First asteroid flyby (951 Gaspra closest approach 1,600 km).
First confirmed observation of an exoplanet.
First polar orbit around the Sun. First mission to survey the space environment above and below the poles of the Sun.
First spacecraft to map Venus in its entirety.
Record longest duration spaceflight to date (437.7 day by Valeri Polyakov).
First orbit of Jupiter.
First spacecraft to enter the atmosphere of a gas giant (Jupiter).
First laser communication from space.
First orbital radio observatory.
First operational rover on another planet (Mars).
First spacecraft to use aerobraking to enter orbit (Martian orbit).
First multinational space station. Largest artificial object built in space to date.
First orbit of an asteroid (433 Eros).
First landing on an asteroid (433 Eros).
First laser communication in space between two objects.
First orbit of Saturn.
First sample return beyond lunar orbit (solar wind).
First landing in the outer Solar System (Titan). First landing on a moon other than Earth's Moon.
First confirmed cryovolcano (Enceladus).
First spacecraft to impact a comet (Tempel 1).
First asteroid ascent (25143 Itokawa). First interplanetary escape without separating and discarding the landing gear.
First sample return from a comet (81P/Wild).
First confirmed lakes on the surface of another celestial body (lakes of Titan).
First spacecraft to photograph another spacecraft landing on another celestial body (Phoenix, on Mars).
First discovery of lunar water in the form of ice.[note 3]
First space telescope designated to search for Earth-like exoplanets.
First images of the structures in the rings of a planet (rings of Saturn).
First solar sail.
First sample return from an asteroid (25143 Itokawa).
First spacecraft to orbit one of the Moon's Lagrange point (L2).
First spacecraft to orbit the Moon's Lagrange 1 point.
First orbit of Mercury.
First orbit of an object in the asteroid belt (4 Vesta).
First use of a sky crane to land on another celestial body (Mars).
First spacecraft to leave the heliosphere. First spacecraft in interstellar space.
First laser communication with a lunar satellite.
First spacecraft to orbit a comet nucleus (67P/Churyumov–Gerasimenko).
First soft landing on a comet (67P/Churyumov–Gerasimenko).
First flyby and orbit of a dwarf planet (Ceres). First spacecraft to orbit two separate celestial bodies.

First flyby of an object beyond Neptune (Pluto and its moons). First flyby in the Kuiper belt. First flyby of a trans-neptunian object. Last original encounter with one of the nine major planets recognized before 2006.
First food grown in space eaten (lettuce).
First observation of gravitational waves.
First propulsive landing of a rocket after sending something into space (suborbital).
First propulsive landing of an orbital rocket.
First inflatable space habitat.[note 4]
First spacecraft to enter the atmosphere of Saturn.
First known interstellar object detected passing through the Solar System.
First operational rover on an asteroid (162173 Ryugu).
First recorded sounds from Mars.
First flyby of a classical Kuiper belt object (486958 Arrokoth). First flyby of a contact binary. First spacecraft to make two different flybys in the Kuiper belt.
First soft landing on the far side of the Moon. First germination of seeds on another celestial body.
First direct photograph of a black hole and its vicinity.
First confirmed quake on another planet (marsquake).
First aerodynamically powered flight on another celestial body (Mars).
First in situ resource utilization. First production of oxygen on another celestial body (Mars).
First spacecraft to fly through the atmosphere of a star (the Sun's corona).
Launch of the largest space telescope to date.
First asteroid measurably deflected by a spacecraft. First spacecraft to make contact with an asteroid moon (impact on Dimorphos).
First landing at the lunar south polar region.
First commercial spacecraft to land on the Moon.
First successful demonstration of in space propellant transfer
